text: this is what the biggest warship ever
built for the Royal Navy looks like the
Queen Elizabeth aircraft carrier under
construction in recite there are 3,000
workers on board busy getting the ship
ready to sail let's go on board and take
a closer look this is the control center
of this massive vessel and they say this
is where it's at it's the heartbeat of
the ship a bit of rivalry between the
control room movie and the bridge
upstairs but from here they control the
six engines that power this vessel two
of them are gas turbine four of them are
diesel each of them the size of a mini
bus they can also run the emergency
response from this control room
controlling the firefighting teams if
that becomes necessary there's enough
power being generated on the ship to
power a city the size of Swindon and all
around the room on the walls what they
call giant iPads monitoring the
condition of the vessel from second to
second for the hundreds of personnel
will be serving on board the Queen
Elizabeth this will be one of the most
important areas it is of course the
galley they will be producing around
five thousand meals a day this is one of
two galleys on board the Queen Elizabeth
and it is the biggest galley in the
Royal Navy
they've also got their own bakery that
too is a first for the Royal Navy and
this galley and the staff here will be
working 24/7 to produce meals around the
clock this is the operations room they
call it the brains of the Queen
Elizabeth it is packed with computer
screens and into this room will flow
information and data not just from the
aircraft carriers on systems but also
from all the other ships and submarines
in the task force that information will
be scanned here by the captain and other
senior members of the crew that will
direct the decisions they make on how to
deploy the weapons systems including the
vertical takeoff and landing aircraft
which will operate from the Queen
Elizabeth that information will be
displayed here there will be a giant
screen they call it the information wall
what you're looking at now believe it or
not is the wheel that steers the Queen
Elizabeth aircraft carrier it's probably
smaller than the steering wheel in your
car at home it's one of the ways they
steer a vessel which is longer than the
houses of parliament were on the bridge
we're about 150 feet or so above
sea-level were protected by three-inch
thick glass and from here the crew have
almost a 360 degree view including most
importantly of course the flight deck
which is over there so they can see
exactly what the aircraft are getting up
to
